subsection.title: A Tool for Solving Exponential Equations
subsection.p: Logarithms are functions that, among other things, can be used to solve exponential equations. If we have an exponential equation in which the variable is in the exponent, we use logarithms to isolate the variable.
By definition, a logarithm is an exponent. In the exponential equation b^{y}=x The exponent y is the logarithm so y=\log_{b}(x)
There are at least three useful rules about logarithms:
The first rule is often used to bring the exponent down after applying the logarithm, the exponent becomes a factor.
The nest two rules are sometimes used to combine two terms involving logarithms, or to split one term into two.
The first rule is perhaps the most useful at this level.

I used to have a pocket knife with 10 different tools folded into it, but I mostly used only one. Rule is that tool. It allows us to take an exponential expression and bring down the exponent so we can isolate it.
If we end up with an equation that looks like (0.337)^{\mathord{?}}=1.272 as in, I wonder what the exponent is?, we can use a logarithmic function to find the answer.
Although most likely a variable is used instead of a question mark, like (0.337)^{x}=1.272 where x is the unknown value we are trying to find.
Using Rule and applying any logarithm to both sides of the equation we can work our way towards isolating the unknown variable x.

example.title: Isolate and solve for the unknown variable

statement.p: In this case we used \log, but we get the same answer using the natural logarithm, \ln, instead. Try it!

It does not matter what base logarithm you use, as long as you use the same \log_{b} on both sides of the equation. However, it does help to use a function that is readily available on most calculators like base 10 (\log), or base e (\ln).

subsection.p: Now you try it. Solve an exponential equation using Rule.

introduction.p: How many 7 \% increases is the same as one 49 \% increase?

statement.p: The growth factor associated with a 7 \% increase is b=.
The equation below literally states, An unknown number of growth factors b=1.07 is the same as 1.49(1.07)^{x}=1.49
Apply your favorite logarithm to each side of the equation. My favorite is \ln, so the equation is now \ln\mathopen{}\left(1.07^x\right)\mathclose{}= \ln(1.49)
Invoke Rule so that the exponent can come down in front of the expression on the left x \ln(1.07)= \ln(1.49)
Last step, isolate the variable by dividing both sides by \ln(1.07), and what do you get?

subsection.p: Rule is great, but if we want to use it as the main tool we have to know when it applies and how to deal with the situation if the rule does not apply.

statement.p: Solve the equation for x 3(2.83)^{x}=15
At first glance it seems you can apply Rule, but is that right? Rule states \log_{b}(N^{x})=x \log_{b}(N)

Notice how Rule assumes you have one side written as N^{x} with nothing else in front (no coefficient). The left side of our equation has a coefficient of 3 in front of the exponential3(2.83)^{x} The constant 3 is keeping us from using Rule. That constant either has to be moved or we have to use another rule (if there is one that applies).
We can fix the situation by rearranging the equation to match the format of Rule or we could use Rule because at least it matches the format of our equation.

solution.p: The constant 3 needs to be moved so only the exponential remains on the left side of the equation.(2.83)^{x}=\frac{15}{3}Voilà! Now we have the correct form to use Rule. Apply your favorite logarithm to both sides. I'll use \ln this time because I used \log in the last example. \ln (2.83)^{x}= \ln \left( \frac{15}{3} \right) The exponent comes down and we have: x \ln(2.83)= \ln \left( \frac{15}{3} \right)The last step is to isolate the variable x= \frac{\ln \left( \frac{15}{3} \right)}{\ln(2.83)} so that (rounded to three decimals): x \approx 1.547
Alternatively, we can use Rule . In English Rule says, The log of a product is equal to the sum of the logs.

Applying \ln to both sides of our equation, we in fact have the log of the product 3 times (2.83)^{x} on the left side \ln (3(2.83)^{x})=\ln(15) Use Rule to write the left side of the equation as the sum of the logs \ln(3)+\ln\mathopen{}\left(2.83^x\right)\mathclose{}=\ln(15) Remember the goal is to isolate the variable x which we can now do since, on the left side, one term has x and the other does not.

Subtracting \ln(3) from both sides we get \ln\mathopen{}\left(2.83^x\right)\mathclose{}=\ln(15)-\ln(3) Look, we get to use Rule anyway! On the left we bring down the exponent, x x \ln(2.83)=\ln(15)-\ln(3) Now isolate x x=\frac{\ln(15)-\ln(3)}{\ln(2.83)} We get the same answer as before x \approx 1.547
Which method did you like better?

introduction.p: Of course we could have just solved the equation 3(2.83)^{x}=15 graphically and avoided the algebra all together.

remark.p: A note about solving. In the two algebra examples we were able to find exact solutions: x= \frac{\ln \big( \frac{15}{3} \big)}{\ln(2.83)} is exact.

We then entered the exact expressions into a calculator and found approximations rounded to three decimal places. Though graphically may seem quick and easy, most often we can only get an approximation to the answer.

subsection.p: Finally, we could just ask a computer to solve the equation for us. Many websites have tools for solving equations. You can enter an equation like: 3(2.83)^x = 15 and then type solve or click a solve button to see the solutions. You may wish to perform a web search for such a website.
We should all be aware that technology can now do much of what only people could do in the past. And we should also be aware of the current limitations of technology.

In fact, computers can solve all kinds of equations, but so far only people have the ability to set the problems up. So the real question is not necessarily Can you solve an equation?,, but Do you have the right equation?

subsection.title: Domain and Range
subsection.p: Because a logarithm is just another kind of function, it has a domain and a range and the graph of a logarithmic function has its own characteristics that make it unique.
We can use our language approach to understand the domain and range of a logarithmic function. Remember the literal translation of the expression \log(x) is The power of 10 that gives you x.

li.p: \log(100) means The power of 10 that gives you 100.
Therefore \log(100)=2 which says, The power of 10 that gives you 100 is 2, since 10^{2}=100.
\log_{3}(81) means, The power of 3 that gives you 81.
Therefore \log_{3}(81)=4 which says, The power of 3 that gives you 81 is 4, since 3^{4}=81

subsection.p: Recall the domain of a function f is the set of all possible inputs the function can use (values that make sense for the function).
Let f(x)=\log_{3}(x) where x is the input.
Consider negative input values, like x=-9 and think about the meaning of \log_{3}(-9):
The statement should make no sense. You cannot get a negative result if all you have is positive 3's multiplied together. At least one has to be negative!
Since any negative input leads us to the same conclusion, it turns out logarithms cannot accept negative inputs.
For a similar reason logarithmic functions cannot have zero as an input. If you ask How many factors of 3 does it take to get 0? or just 3^{\mathord{?}}=0, it should be clear there is no answer.
Therefore, the domain of any logarithmic function is all inputs that are greater than or equal to zero.

For the range we must consider all the possible outputs of the function. In the case of the logarithm, an output is the exponent value needed to get a particular input \log_{b}(\text{input})=\text{output}

statement.p: Consider again y=\log_{3}(x).
For any input x how many 3's does it take to get that x-value? The answer (output) is the y-value.
For inputs between zero and one, 0 \lt x \lt 1, the results are negative, so y \lt 0.
For inputs greater than one, x \gt 1, the results are always positive, so y \gt 0
If the input is x=1 the result is always zero \log_{3}(1)=0 because, The power of 3 that gives you 1 is the 0 power.
After a few tries we should begin to realize the range of \log_{3}(x) is all real numbers.

subsection.p: It turns out the range for any base of a log function like \log_{b}(x) is all real numbers.

subsection.title: Change of Base
subsection.p: So far, when evaluating expressions like \log_{3}(9) it seems we need to know the answer before we evaluate. How do you evaluate an expression when you don't already know the answer?

example.p: We know the answer should be negative because we are trying to get 0.1822 which is less than 1.

Your calculator may already have a log of any base option. Today, in the 21st century we can also find the answer, for free, on the web. For instance, go to Desmos.com. Type log_(0.1822) into one of the cells. You should see the answer as \log_{3}(0.1822) \approx -1.5498 and you can get more decimal places if you want.

But before the web, it used to be that calculators only had one or two options for logarithms, (and before calculators there were things called slide rules and books with pages and pages of tables of logarithms).

Here is an old school method of evaluating a logarithm expression. The method is called change of base which means you change the base from whatever it is to either base 10, \log, or base e, \ln, because most calculators have those built in.

Set up an equation in which y is the answer you want. Then use the definition of the logarithm to turn the log_{b} equation into an exponential equation. The last step is to solve the exponential equation using the most convenient logarithm at your disposal (most likely log or ln). In this example we use log-base-10, \log. \log_{3}(0.1822)\amp=y 0.1822\amp=3^{y} \log(0.1822)\amp=\log(3^{y}) \log(0.1822)\amp=y\log(3) y\amp=\frac{\log(0.1822)}{\log(3)} y\amp\approx -1.5498

statement.p: A radioactive substance has a continuous hourly decay rate of \%.
What is the percent hourly decay rate?

The opening sentence is telling us we must use an exponential model because the decay rate is a constant percent. The sentence goes on to tell us what kind of decay model and the percent rate of decay.

The word continuous is telling us to use base e. Therefore we can write the formula for decay as Ae^{kt} where k is the continuous decay constant k=. This value is negative because we are told the 21 \% is a decrease.
The value A represents the initial amount of substance, but it was not stated. So we put a variable there to hold its place.
The question is about the hourly percent decay. But, we were given the continuous hourly decay. These are two different things.

A discrete model would look like Ab^{t} where b is the hourly growth factor we are trying to find. But both the discrete and continuous models have to predict the same behavior. Therefore the two formulas have to be equal they have to produce the same values. A(b)^{t}=A(e^{-k})^t Notice how the parentheses are used to show that both sides are actually the same thing. Both say A(\text{something})^{t}. The somethings must be the same number. That is: b = e^{-k}.
With k= then b= (round to 4 significant digits).
Therefore, the percent hourly rate of decay is (include units).
What is the half-life of the substance?
The half-life is the time is takes to reduce the substance to half its value. We do not know how much substance there is, but we do know there is something.
Earlier we called the initial amount A. In some time we will have \frac{1}{2}A. How much time? The answer is the half-life.
The half-life is t \approx (Include units and round to 2 decimal places).

exercise.title: Population Growth and Time to Triple

statement.p: A population increases at an annual rate of about \%.
What is the continuous annual growth rate?
The opening sentence is telling us we must use an exponential model because the growth is a constant percent. The sentence goes on to tell us what kind of growth model and the percent rate of growth.

Annual percent growth is called discrete growth. Not because it is annual, per se, but because it is measured at the end of some finite time interval. Other examples of discrete growth (or decay) would be described as monthly or daily etc. Another way to tell it is discrete is the absence of the word continuous. If the growth is not continuous, then it is discrete.
A discrete model looks like Ab^{t} where in our case b is the annual growth factor and A represents the initial size of the population which we are not given.
A continuous model would be Ae^{kt} where k is the continuous growth constant and A still represents the initial amount.
These models must be equal because they are describing the same population. Therefore A(b)^{t}=A(e^{k})^{t} Notice what is the same on each side and what is different.
In order to be equal b=e^{k}.
Solving the equation for k: b\amp=e^{k} \ln(b)\amp= \ln(e^{k}) \ln(b)\amp=k \ln(e) \ln(b)\amp=k
The continuous growth constant in our problem is k \approx (round your answer to 2 decimal places).
This represents a continuous percent growth rate of about Include units and round to 2 decimal places).

In the study of populations (population dynamics) the situation often arises where we must solve logarithmic equations.

For instance, when searching for an equation to model a population that has a carrying capacity (a maximum number the population can sustain) we can end up with an equation like \ln(P)-\ln(1-P)=tin which the goal is to isolate P as a function of t. It is a good exercise in algebra and log rules.
Use Rule to write the left side of the equation \ln(P)-\ln(1-P)=t as one term.
Use the definition of the logarithm that states \log_{b}(x)=y means b^{y}=x, to rewrite the equation \ln(\frac{P}{1-P})=t as an exponential equation \frac{P}{1-P}=e^{t}
Multiply both sides of the equation \frac{P}{1-P}=e^{t} by (1-P) and distribute on the right side to get P=e^{t}-Pe^{t}
Collect the terms with P on the left of P+Pe^{t}=e^{t} and factor out P so that P(1+e^{t})=e^{t}
Now solve for P to get the final answer.
This kind of equation is called logistical and you will study it more in-depth if you continue your studies through calculus.

Hick's Law (named for psychologist William Edmund Hick) says that when people must make a choice from a set of options, the time it takes them increases logarithmically as the number of possible options increases.

In particular, the law says that the time, T, it takes to make a choice can be modeled by the equation T = b \log_2(n+1) where n represents the number of options from which to choose, and b is a constant number related to factors such as the type of decision being made.

statement.p: The frequency of a musical tone defines the pitch we hear, which we may give a note value (such as G or D). Mathematically, frequency is measured in hertz. A higher number of hertz for a tone means the tone sounds higher.

On a piano, we have the following notes: A, A, B, C, C, D, D, E, F, F, G, G, A. This is called one octave of notes, and these same notes repeat in the next octave (just at higher frequencies). We call the distance between successive notes in an octave a semitone. So, the distance from A to C is 3 semitones, and the distance between A and the next A is 12 semitones.
Now, the note middle A has a frequency of 440 Hertz. To calculate the frequency of a note, we use the formula F(x) = 440(2)^{x/12} where x is the number of semitones a note is above middle A.
What note has a frequency of 1046.5 Hertz?
Answer:

solution.p: The note is 15 semitones above middle A. Since the next A is 12 semitones above middle A, those extra 3 semitones mean we are at the note C.

statement.p: A famous application involving the number e comes from Optimal Stopping theory. Known as the Best Choice Problem, it concerns hiring someone for a job under the following conditions:

li.p: You have n people to interview.
You interview them one-by-one.
After each person is interviewed, you must immediately make the decision of whether to hire them or not. If you hire them, you're done and you cannot interview anymore candidates.
If you reject a candidate (decide not to hire them), you can't change your mind later.

statement.p: Under these conditions, you may wonder how to actually choose the best person for the job. If you choose a good candidate early on, you may miss the opportunity to hire a really great candidate later down the line. If you wait too long, you may only be left with mediocre candidates from which to choose.

The solution is to interview the first \frac{n}{e} candidates but reject all of them, regardless of their qualifications. Then, continue interviewing candidates until you find the first one that is better than the first group you rejected. Hire this person.
Interestingly, this simple rule has been shown to find the best candidate in a group approximately 37 \% of the time, no matter the size of the group!
